contentrichtext.text: {{lunar crater data | image=[[File:Moon-craters.jpg|200px]]| caption=''The lunar farside crater Daedalus from [[Apollo 11]]. [[NASA]] photo.''| latitude=5.9| N_or_S=S| longitude=179.4| E_or_W=E| diameter=93 km| depth=3.0 km| colong=181| eponym=[[Daedalus]]}} [[Image:Daedalus crater 2033 med.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lunar Orbiter 2]] image]] '''Daedalus''' is a prominent [[Impact crater|crater]] located near the center of the [[Far side of the Moon|far side]] of the [[Moon]]. The inner wall is [[wiktionary:terrace|terrace]]d, and there is a cluster of central peaks on the relatively flat floor. Because of its location (shielded from radio emissions from the [[Earth]]), it has been proposed as the site of a future giant [[radio telescope]], which would be scooped out of the crater itself, much like the [[Arecibo radio telescope]], but on a vastly larger scale. The crater is named after [[Daedalus]] of [[Greek myth]]. It is pictured in famous photographs taken by the [[Apollo 11]] astronauts. In contemporary sources it was called "Crater 308" (this was a temporary [[International Astronomical Union|IAU]] designation that preceded the establishment of far-side lunar nomenclature). Nearby craters of note include [[Icarus (crater)|Icarus]] to the east and [[Racah (crater)|Racah]] to the south. Less than a crater diameter to the north-northeast is [[Lipskiy (crater)|Lipskiy]]. ==Satellite craters== By convention these features are identified on lunar maps by placing the letter on the side of the crater midpoint that is closest to Daedalus. {| class="wikitable" !width="25%" style="background:#eeeeee;" |Daedalus !width="25%" style="background:#eeeeee;" |Latitude !width="25%" style="background:#eeeeee;" |Longitude !width="25%" style="background:#eeeeee;" |Diameter |- |align="center"|B |align="center"|4.1° S |align="center"|179.8° W |align="center"|23 km |- |align="center"|C |align="center"|4.1° S |align="center"|178.9° W |align="center"|68 km |- |align="center"|G |align="center"|6.6° S |align="center"|177.4° W |align="center"|33 km |- |align="center"|K |align="center"|8.3° S |align="center"|178.5° W |align="center"|24 km |- |align="center"|M |align="center"|8.1° S |align="center"|179.5° E |align="center"|13 km |- |align="center"|R |align="center"|7.7° S |align="center"|175.2° E |align="center"|41 km |- |align="center"|S |align="center"|6.8° S |align="center"|172.9° E |align="center"|20 km |- |align="center"|U |align="center"|4.2° S |align="center"|174.9° E |align="center"|30 km |- |align="center"|W |align="center"|3.5° S |align="center"|177.5° E |align="center"|70 km |} ==References== * {{cite web | last = Graham-Rowe | first = Duncan | date = 2002-01-03 | url = http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn1735 | title = Astronomers plan telescope on Moon | publisher = New Scientist | accessdate = 2006-10-25 }} {{Lunar crater references}} ==External links== * [http://www.lpi.usra.edu/research/lunar_orbiter/bin/info.shtml?41 Lunar Orbiter photographic atlas, Photo Number II-033-M] [[Category:Impact craters on the Moon]]
